sections.content: Property management makes or breaks real estate investing. Excellent management means reliable cash flow, happy tenants, and preserved property value. Poor management means constant headaches, vacancy, damages, and legal issues. You can self-manage or hire professionals—both have trade-offs. Understanding management fundamentals is essential regardless of which path you choose.

sections.title: Self-Management vs Property Manager
items: Self-manage: No management fee (save 8-10%), direct control, learn business, requires time and availability
Property manager: Pay 8-10% of rent, professional handling, scalable, less control, quality varies widely
When to self-manage: 1-3 local properties, time available, want hands-on experience
When to hire: 4+ properties, out-of-state, busy career, value your time highly
Hybrid: Self-manage initially to learn, hire manager as you scale
Cost: $100/month management fee is worth it if saves 10+ hours monthly

sections.content: Tenant screening is your most important management task. Good tenants pay on time, maintain property, stay long-term, and cause few issues. Bad tenants cost thousands in lost rent, damages, evictions, and stress. Thorough screening takes 1-2 hours but prevents months of problems. Never skip screening to fill vacancy faster.

sections.title: Tenant Screening Process
items: Minimum criteria: 3x rent income, 620+ credit score, no evictions, verify employment
Application: Complete application with rental history, employment, references
Credit check: Review score, payment history, accounts, debt levels
Background check: Criminal history, eviction records, sex offender registry
Income verification: Pay stubs, bank statements, tax returns for self-employed
Reference calls: Previous landlords (not current, they might lie to get rid of bad tenant)
Meeting: In-person or video meeting to assess responsibility and communication

sections.title: Lease Agreements
items: Use attorney-reviewed lease: State-specific, covers legal requirements
Length: 12-month lease typical, month-to-month gives flexibility but less stability
Rent amount: Market rate, specify due date and late fees
Security deposit: Typically one month's rent, follow state laws on holding/returning
Maintenance responsibilities: Clearly define landlord vs tenant responsibilities
Rules: Pets, smoking, guests, parking, noise policies all in writing
Move-in inspection: Document condition with photos, signed checklist

sections.content: Maintenance response time affects tenant satisfaction and retention. Same-day response for emergencies (no heat, no water, flooding), 24-48 hours for urgent issues, 3-7 days for routine maintenance. Have reliable contractor relationships established before emergencies occur. Preventive maintenance saves money compared to emergency repairs.

sections.title: Key Management Tasks
items: Rent collection: Online payment systems, enforce late fees consistently
Maintenance coordination: Respond promptly, use reliable contractors, document everything
Property inspections: Quarterly exterior, annual interior to catch issues early
Accounting: Track income/expenses meticulously, separate bank account for each property
Communication: Respond to tenant inquiries within 24 hours
Legal compliance: Follow Fair Housing, state/local landlord-tenant laws
Turnovers: Clean, repair, upgrade between tenants, minimize vacancy time

sections.title: Management Mistakes
items: Poor screening: Desperate to fill vacancy leads to bad tenants
Verbal agreements: Everything must be in writing
Inconsistent enforcement: Enforcing rules selectively creates legal liability
Delayed maintenance: Small issues become expensive when ignored
No documentation: Not documenting communications, conditions, repairs
Over-involvement: Being available 24/7, train tenants to respect boundaries
Under-involvement: Not conducting inspections, discovering major issues too late

quiz.question: What's the most important property management task?
options: Thorough tenant screening to select quality tenants
quiz.explanation: Thorough tenant screening is most important. Good tenants prevent most other problems (late rent, damages, evictions).

quiz.question: When should you hire a property manager?
options: When you have 4+ properties, out-of-state properties, or limited time
quiz.explanation: Consider property managers when you have 4+ properties, invest out-of-state, or your time is worth more than the 8-10% management fee.

sections.content: Good tenants are assets worth keeping. Tenant turnover costs 1-2 months rent in vacancy, cleaning, repairs, marketing, and screening. A tenant who stays 5 years instead of 1 year saves you thousands. Treating tenants professionally while maintaining boundaries creates stable, profitable rentals. The goal: professional landlord-tenant relationship, not friendship.

sections.title: Building Positive Relationships
items: Responsive communication: Reply to inquiries within 24 hours
Quick maintenance: Fix issues promptly, especially those affecting habitability
Respect privacy: Give 24 hours notice before entry, don't drop by unannounced
Fair treatment: Enforce rules consistently, don't discriminate
Professionalism: Business relationship, not friendship, maintains appropriate boundaries
Small gestures: Holiday card, move-in gift basket builds goodwill affordably

sections.content: Retention starts at move-in. Good first impression, smooth process, and quick response to early issues set positive tone. Many landlords lose good tenants through neglect—slow responses, ignoring maintenance, treating tenants as adversaries. Professional, respectful treatment costs nothing and dramatically improves retention.

sections.title: Retention Strategies
items: Competitive pricing: Market-rate renewals, not automatic 10% increases
Property condition: Keep property well-maintained, address issues proactively
Upgrade incentives: Offer minor upgrades for lease renewal (new appliance, paint)
Flexible lease terms: Consider tenant requests (early renewal, month-to-month extension)
Long-term discounts: Small discount for 24-month lease vs 12-month
Good tenant rewards: Waive rent increase for exceptional long-term tenants

sections.title: Handling Issues
items: Late rent: Follow policy, charge late fees consistently, communicate consequences
Noise complaints: Warn first, document, escalate to lease violation if continues
Unauthorized occupants: Address immediately, violates lease, creates liability
Property damage: Document with photos, charge for repairs beyond normal wear
Lease violations: Written warnings, document, follow escalation procedure
Difficult personalities: Professional distance, document everything, don't engage emotionally

sections.content: Document everything. Email is your friend—creates paper trail of all communications, requests, and agreements. Photos document property condition at move-in, during tenancy, and at move-out. This documentation protects you legally and prevents disputes over deposits, damages, and agreements.

sections.title: When to Evict
items: Non-payment: 2-3 months unpaid rent, payment plan failed, no communication
Lease violations: Repeated violations after warnings, serious single violation
Illegal activity: Drug dealing, violence, criminal activity
Property damage: Intentional destruction beyond normal wear
Legal process: Follow state laws exactly, hire attorney, don't self-help evict
Cost: $1,000-3,000 in legal fees, 2-6 months to complete

quiz.question: How much does tenant turnover typically cost?
options: 1-2 months rent in vacancy, cleaning, repairs, and marketing
quiz.explanation: Tenant turnover costs 1-2 months rent when accounting for vacancy, cleaning, repairs, marketing, and screening time.

quiz.question: What's the best retention strategy?
options: Professional service, responsive maintenance, competitive renewals
quiz.explanation: Professional service, responsive maintenance, and competitive renewal rates retain good tenants better than being friends or undercharging rent.

sections.content: Real estate offers extraordinary tax benefits that amplify returns. Depreciation creates paper losses that offset income. Expense deductions reduce taxable income. 1031 exchanges defer capital gains indefinitely. These tax advantages are why real estate is wealth-building vehicle of choice for high earners. Understanding and using these benefits legally is essential for maximizing returns.

sections.title: Depreciation
items: What it is: IRS allows you to deduct property value over 27.5 years (residential)
How it works: $275k building value ÷ 27.5 years = $10k annual deduction
Paper loss: Creates tax deduction without actual cash expense
Land exception: Land doesn't depreciate, only building value
Example: $10k depreciation offsets $10k rental income, pay $0 tax on cash flow
Recapture: When you sell, depreciation is taxed at 25%, still better than deferring

sections.content: Cost segregation accelerates depreciation. Engineering study identifies components (carpets, appliances, landscaping) that depreciate faster than 27.5 years. This front-loads deductions, creating larger early tax benefits. Worth doing on properties $500k+ or portfolios. Costs $5k-15k but can create $50k-200k in early deductions.

sections.title: Deductible Expenses
items: Operating expenses: Property management, repairs, maintenance, supplies
Property costs: Insurance, property taxes, HOA fees, utilities if you pay
Professional services: Accounting, legal, property management fees
Travel: Mileage/travel to check properties, meet contractors, show units
Home office: If you have dedicated space for managing properties
Education: Books, courses, conferences about real estate investing
Marketing: Advertising for tenants, website, signage

sections.title: 1031 Exchange
items: Purpose: Defer capital gains tax by reinvesting proceeds into like-kind property
Requirements: Investment property to investment property, use qualified intermediary
Timeline: Identify replacement within 45 days, close within 180 days
Benefits: Defer taxes indefinitely by continuously exchanging properties
Rules: Same or greater value, equal or more debt, can't touch proceeds
Strategy: Upgrade portfolio over time while deferring taxes
Death step-up: Heirs receive stepped-up basis, avoiding all deferred gains

sections.content: Real estate professional status unlocks unlimited passive loss deductions. Requirements: spend 750+ hours in real estate AND more than any other work. Allows you to deduct real estate losses against W2 income. Powerful for high earners with spouses who can qualify. Requires documentation and careful planning.

sections.title: Other Tax Strategies
items: Primary residence exclusion: $250k/$500k capital gains tax-free if lived 2 of last 5 years
House hack then sell: Live in multi-family 2 years, use primary residence exclusion
Opportunity zones: Invest in designated areas for capital gains deferral/reduction
LLC/entity structure: Liability protection, potential tax benefits with S-corp election
Self-directed IRA: Buy real estate in retirement account, all gains tax-deferred
Augusta rule: Rent primary home 14 days annually tax-free (great for short-term rentals)

sections.title: Tax Mistakes
items: Poor record keeping: Missing deductions due to lack of documentation
Not using depreciation: Leaving money on table by not claiming depreciation
DIY complex taxes: Real estate tax code is complex, use specialized CPA
Mixing personal and business: Commingled funds create audit issues
Selling without 1031: Paying unnecessary capital gains tax
Not tracking basis: Can't prove improvements, pay more tax at sale

quiz.question: What is depreciation in real estate?
options: Tax deduction for building value over 27.5 years
quiz.explanation: Depreciation is a tax deduction allowing you to write off residential building value over 27.5 years, creating paper losses that offset income.

quiz.question: What is a 1031 exchange?
options: Strategy to defer capital gains by reinvesting in like-kind property
quiz.explanation: 1031 exchange lets you defer capital gains taxes indefinitely by reinvesting sale proceeds into another investment property within specific timelines.

sections.content: Insurance protects your investment from catastrophic losses. Proper coverage means a fire, lawsuit, or natural disaster doesn't wipe out your wealth. Under-insurance is common mistake—investors trying to save $200/year leave themselves exposed to $200k+ losses. Understanding what coverage you need and what's actually covered prevents financial disasters.

sections.title: Types of Property Insurance
items: Dwelling coverage: Rebuilds structure if destroyed, insure for replacement cost not market value
Liability coverage: Protects against lawsuits (slip and fall, injury), minimum $1M recommended
Loss of rents: Pays lost rental income if property uninhabitable, typically 6-12 months
Personal property: Covers your equipment (appliances, maintenance tools)
Flood insurance: Separate policy if in flood zone, worth considering even if not required
Earthquake insurance: Separate in earthquake zones, expensive but necessary

sections.content: Landlord insurance costs 15-25% more than homeowner insurance. Why? Higher risks from tenant damage, vacancy, and liability exposure. Don't use homeowner policy on rental—it won't cover rental activities and claims could be denied. Always disclose property is rental to insurance company.

sections.title: Umbrella Liability Policy
items: What it is: Additional liability coverage beyond property policy limits
Coverage: Typically $1M-5M additional protection
Cost: Remarkably cheap, $200-500 annually for $1M coverage
Protection: Covers across all properties and personal liability
Requirements: Usually need $300k/$500k auto and $300k property liability first
Essential: More properties = more liability exposure, umbrella policy is crucial

sections.title: Entity Structure Protection
items: LLC benefits: Liability protection, separates personal and business assets
Series LLC: One parent LLC with multiple sub-LLCs, each property isolated
Cost: $100-500 annually per LLC depending on state
Maintenance: Must maintain separate accounts, proper records for protection
Financing challenge: Many lenders won't lend to LLCs, require personal guarantees
Strategy: Buy in personal name, transfer to LLC after closing (check with lender)

sections.content: Insurance and entity structure work together. LLC protects you if tenant sues, but building burns down with inadequate insurance, LLC won't help—you still lose the asset. Conversely, great insurance but no entity means tenant slip-and-fall lawsuit can reach personal assets. Layer your protections.

sections.title: Risk Management Practices
items: Regular inspections: Identify hazards before they cause injuries
Prompt repairs: Fix safety issues immediately
Quality tenants: Screen well, reducing likelihood of problems
Documentation: Photos, communications, maintenance records protect in disputes
Local code compliance: Follow housing codes, safety regulations
Professional help: Use licensed contractors for repairs, especially electrical/plumbing
Winterization: Prevent frozen pipes in vacant properties

sections.title: Insurance Mistakes
items: Under-insuring: Saving on premium, exposed to massive loss
Wrong policy type: Using homeowner policy on rental property
No umbrella: Leaving personal assets exposed to lawsuits
Not updating coverage: Property improvements not reflected in coverage
No loss of rents: No income protection during repairs
Skipping flood insurance: 'Not in flood zone' but flash flooding still possible
Cheap coverage: Lowest price often means inadequate coverage or bad service

quiz.question: Why does landlord insurance cost more than homeowner insurance?
options: Rental properties have higher risks: tenant damage, vacancy, liability
Only if you have bad tenants
quiz.explanation: Landlord insurance costs 15-25% more due to higher risks: tenant damage, vacancy periods, increased liability exposure from renters.

quiz.question: What is an umbrella liability policy?
options: Additional liability coverage beyond property policy limits
Coverage for umbrellas left at property
quiz.explanation: Umbrella policies provide additional liability coverage (typically $1M-5M) beyond property policy limits, protecting personal assets from lawsuits.

sections.content: Maintenance and capital expenditures (CapEx) are unavoidable costs of real estate ownership. Maintenance covers ongoing repairs; CapEx covers major component replacements (roof, HVAC, appliances). New investors often budget inadequately for these, leading to cash flow problems. Understanding the difference and budgeting properly prevents financial surprises.

sections.title: Maintenance vs CapEx
items: Maintenance: Repairs that keep property in current condition (leaky faucet, broken outlet)
CapEx: Replacements that extend property life (new roof, HVAC, water heater)
Tax treatment: Maintenance is immediately deductible; CapEx is depreciated over time
Budgeting: Maintenance is 5-10% of rent; CapEx is 5-10% of rent, both reserves needed
Example: Fixing AC is maintenance; replacing entire AC system is CapEx

sections.content: Component lifecycles: Roof 20-30 years ($8k-25k), HVAC 15-20 years ($5k-15k), water heater 10-12 years ($800-2k), appliances 8-15 years ($500-2k each), flooring 5-10 years ($3k-10k), paint 3-5 years ($2k-5k). Know component ages when buying and budget for replacements.

sections.title: Building CapEx Reserves
items: Monthly contributions: Set aside 5-10% of rent into separate savings account
Property-specific: Each property should have its own reserve account
Target amount: 6-12 months operating expenses plus upcoming CapEx
Prioritization: If limited funds, prioritize properties with older components
Don't raid reserves: Resist temptation to use for other purposes
Refinance strategy: When refinancing, pull cash for CapEx reserves

sections.title: Preventive Maintenance
items: HVAC: Filter changes quarterly, professional service annually ($150-300)
Gutters: Clean twice yearly, prevents water damage ($100-200)
Plumbing: Check for leaks, water heater flush annually ($0-100)
Exterior: Inspect and repair caulking, paint as needed
Appliances: Professional cleaning (HVAC, dryer vents, dishwasher)
Landscaping: Regular maintenance prevents expensive replacements
Cost vs benefit: $500 annually in preventive maintenance saves $5,000 emergency repairs

sections.content: Emergency fund separate from CapEx reserves. CapEx is planned (you know roof will need replacing eventually). Emergency fund covers unexpected disasters: major leak, vandalism, sudden system failure, eviction costs. Aim for $5k-10k per property in true emergency funds.

sections.title: Contractor Relationships
items: Build team before needed: Don't scramble during emergency
Key contractors: HVAC, plumber, electrician, general handyman, roofer
Vetting: License verification, insurance, references, test with small jobs
Multiple options: Have 2-3 contractors per category for comparison/backup
Negotiation: Volume discount if you have multiple properties
Payment: Never pay full amount upfront, tie payment to completion
DIY vs hire: Do what you're good at, hire experts for specialized work

sections.title: Maintenance Mistakes
items: Deferred maintenance: Ignoring small issues until they become expensive
No reserves: Living cash-flow to cash-flow, unable to handle expenses
Wrong priorities: Upgrading cosmetics while ignoring failing HVAC
Cheap materials: Using lowest-quality materials requires more frequent replacement
No prevention: Skipping preventive maintenance, only doing reactive repairs
Wrong contractor: Using unlicensed handyman for major work
DIY everything: Wasting time on tasks contractor does better/faster

quiz.question: What's the difference between maintenance and CapEx?
options: Maintenance is repairs; CapEx is major replacements that extend life
CapEx is only for commercial properties
Maintenance is what tenants pay for
quiz.explanation: Maintenance covers ongoing repairs to maintain current condition. CapEx covers major component replacements (roof, HVAC) that extend property life.

quiz.question: How much should you budget for maintenance and CapEx combined?
quiz.explanation: Budget 5-10% of rent for ongoing maintenance and 5-10% for CapEx reserves—10-20% total. This prevents cash flow problems when expenses arise.
